content.title: Phillips Curve
content.definition: The Phillips curve describes the empirical inverse relationship between unemployment and inflation (or wage growth). Originally discovered by A.W. Phillips (1958) for UK wages, it was interpreted as a stable policy tradeoff: lower unemployment could be achieved at the cost of higher inflation. The expectations-augmented Phillips curve (Friedman-Phelps) modified this: π = πᵉ - β(u - uⁿ), showing that the tradeoff only exists when actual inflation differs from expected inflation. In the long run, when expectations adjust, there is no tradeoff - the long-run Phillips curve is vertical at the natural rate of unemployment (NAIRU).

definitions_glossary.phillips_curve: Empirical relationship showing inverse correlation between unemployment rate and inflation rate (or wage growth)
definitions_glossary.original_phillips_curve: A.W. Phillips's 1958 finding: historical UK data showed stable negative relationship between wage inflation and unemployment
definitions_glossary.expectations_augmented_phillips_curve: Friedman-Phelps modification: π = πᵉ - β(u - uⁿ) + ε, tradeoff depends on inflation surprise
definitions_glossary.nairu: Non-Accelerating Inflation Rate of Unemployment - unemployment rate where inflation remains stable (neither rising nor falling)
definitions_glossary.natural_rate_of_unemployment: Unemployment rate when labor market in equilibrium - includes frictional and structural but not cyclical unemployment
definitions_glossary.inflation_expectations: πᵉ = anticipated future inflation rate - key determinant of actual inflation and wage demands
definitions_glossary.adaptive_expectations: Expectations based on past inflation: πᵉ = π₋₁ - people expect recent inflation to continue
definitions_glossary.rational_expectations: Expectations use all available information: πᵉ = E[π|I] - people don't make systematic forecast errors
definitions_glossary.sacrifice_ratio: Percentage points of GDP lost per 1 percentage point reduction in inflation - cost of disinflation
definitions_glossary.short_run_phillips_curve: Downward-sloping curve given fixed πᵉ - shows temporary tradeoff exploitable by surprise inflation
definitions_glossary.long_run_phillips_curve: Vertical line at uⁿ - no tradeoff when expectations fully adjust (πᵉ = π)
definitions_glossary.accelerationist_hypothesis: Below NAIRU → inflation accelerates continuously; above NAIRU → inflation decelerates
definitions_glossary.supply_shock: ε term in Phillips curve - events (oil price spikes) that shift the short-run Phillips curve

key_points: Original Phillips curve (1958): Stable inverse relationship between wage inflation and unemployment in UK data (1861-1957)
Policy interpretation (1960s): Permanent tradeoff - policymakers can choose point on curve (low u/high π or high u/low π)
Friedman-Phelps critique (1967-68): Tradeoff only temporary - expectations adjust, eliminating long-run tradeoff
Expectations-augmented form: π = πᵉ - β(u - uⁿ) + ε. Inflation = expected inflation - β×(unemployment gap) + supply shocks
NAIRU/Natural rate: When u = uⁿ, inflation equals expected inflation (stable). Below uⁿ → inflation accelerates
Short-run curve shifts: Changes in πᵉ shift SRPC up/down. Higher expected inflation → higher actual inflation at each u
Long-run vertical: When πᵉ = π, u = uⁿ regardless of inflation level. No long-run tradeoff.
Stagflation explained: 1970s oil shocks shifted SRPC up (ε > 0) → high inflation AND high unemployment
Sacrifice ratio: Volcker disinflation (1980-83) cost ~2.5% of GDP per 1pp inflation reduction
Modern debate: Is Phillips curve flattening? Globalization, anchored expectations may have changed slope

examples.title: Original Phillips Curve - UK 1861-1957
examples.description: A.W. Phillips plotted UK wage inflation against unemployment for nearly 100 years. Found remarkably stable negative relationship: 5.5% unemployment → 0% wage inflation, 2.5% unemployment → 2% wage inflation. Interpretation: labor market tightness drives wage demands. Lower unemployment → workers have more bargaining power → higher wage growth. This empirical regularity seemed to offer policymakers a menu of inflation-unemployment combinations.
examples.context: The original empirical discovery that launched the Phillips curve literature
examples.data: Phillips (1958): Wage inflation W: -0.9% at u=5.5%, +2% at u=2.5%, +9% at u=1.5%. 97 years of data fit one curve

examples.title: 1970s Stagflation - Phillips Curve Breakdown
examples.description: 1960s saw stable Phillips curve trade-off in US. Then 1970s: both inflation AND unemployment rose. 1975: inflation 9.1%, unemployment 8.5%. 1980: inflation 13.5%, unemployment 7.1%. How? (1) Oil shocks shifted SRPC up (supply shock ε). (2) Inflation expectations rose as Fed accommodated shocks. SRPC kept shifting up. Proved Friedman-Phelps: no stable long-run trade-off. Led to expectations-augmented Phillips curve becoming standard.
examples.context: Empirical crisis that validated expectations-augmented theory

examples.title: Volcker Disinflation 1980-1983
examples.description: Fed Chair Volcker raised rates to 20% to break 13% inflation. Unemployment rose to 10.8% (1982). By 1983: inflation 3%, unemployment falling. Movement along SRPC (contractionary demand → lower inflation, higher unemployment). Then SRPC shifted down as inflation expectations fell (πᵉ dropped). Sacrifice ratio: ~2.5 (lost ~6% cumulative GDP to reduce inflation 10 points). Demonstrated: disinflation possible but costly.
examples.context: Deliberate movement along and shifting of Phillips curve

examples.title: 1990s 'Goldilocks' Economy - Flattening Phillips Curve?
examples.description: Late 1990s US: unemployment fell to 4% (below estimated NAIRU of 5-6%) but inflation stayed low (~2%). Standard Phillips curve predicted higher inflation. Explanations: (1) NAIRU lower than estimated (productivity boom reduced it), (2) Globalization flattened curve (competition limits price increases), (3) Fed credibility anchored expectations. Debate: Has Phillips curve become flatter (less responsive to unemployment)?
examples.context: Apparent Phillips curve puzzle - low unemployment without inflation
examples.data: US 1999: Unemployment 4.0%, Core PCE 1.5%. Estimated NAIRU: 5-6%. Phillips curve prediction: inflation should rise

examples.title: Post-2020 Inflation Debate
examples.description: COVID recovery: unemployment fell rapidly (14.7% to 3.5% by 2022). Inflation surged to 9%. Questions: (1) Was this Phillips curve working (tight labor → inflation)? (2) Or supply shocks (ε) from supply chains? (3) Or unanchored expectations? Fed initially called inflation 'transitory' (supply shock view). Later acknowledged demand side role. Illustrates ongoing relevance of Phillips curve framework for policy.
examples.context: Modern application of Phillips curve analysis

content.statement: The Phillips curve represents one of the most important relationships in macroeconomics, describing the short-run tradeoff between unemployment and inflation. Understanding how expectations modify this relationship - creating only a temporary tradeoff that disappears in the long run - is essential for analyzing monetary policy, disinflation strategies, and macroeconomic stabilization.

explanation.intuition: Think of the Phillips curve as describing labor market pressure on prices. When unemployment is low, workers are scarce. Businesses must offer higher wages to attract and retain employees. These higher labor costs get passed on as higher prices - inflation. When unemployment is high, workers are abundant. They accept lower wages, cost pressures ease, inflation falls. BUT there's a catch: if workers expect 3% inflation, they demand 3% wage increases just to stay even. Only if actual inflation SURPRISES them (differs from expectations) does the tradeoff work. That's why you can't keep pushing unemployment below natural rate - eventually everyone expects the higher inflation, demands higher wages, and unemployment returns to its natural rate, but now with permanently higher inflation.
explanation.key_insight: The key insight is the distinction between short-run and long-run. In the short run (given fixed expectations), policymakers face a tradeoff: stimulate economy → lower u → higher π. But this tradeoff is temporary. As people adjust expectations upward, the short-run curve shifts up. To maintain low unemployment, you need ever-increasing inflation (accelerationist hypothesis). In the long run, the only stable point is where actual inflation equals expected inflation - at the natural rate of unemployment. This is why most economists believe: (1) Monetary policy can't permanently reduce unemployment below the natural rate, (2) Disinflation requires temporary recession (moving up the curve), (3) Credibility matters - if expectations adjust quickly, disinflation is less costly.
explanation.technical_details: Expectations-augmented Phillips curve: π = πᵉ - β(u - uⁿ) + ε. Variables: π = inflation, πᵉ = expected inflation, u = unemployment, uⁿ = natural rate (NAIRU), ε = supply shock. Coefficient β measures responsiveness (~0.5 historically). Alternative form (output gap): π = πᵉ + γ(Y - Y*)/Y* + ε. With adaptive expectations: πᵉ = π₋₁, so π - π₋₁ = -β(u - uⁿ) + ε (change in inflation depends on u gap). Long-run: Set π = πᵉ (expectations correct). Then 0 = -β(u - uⁿ) + ε, implying u = uⁿ + ε/β. Without shocks (ε=0): u = uⁿ at any stable inflation rate. NAIRU estimation: Where inflation stable (Δπ = 0). Sacrifice ratio = Σ(u - uⁿ) / Δπ - cumulative unemployment cost per point of disinflation.

mathematical_formulation.expectations_augmented_pc: π = πᵉ - β(u - uⁿ) + ε where β > 0
mathematical_formulation.output_gap_form: π = πᵉ + γ(Y - Y*)/Y* + ε via Okun's law
mathematical_formulation.adaptive_expectations: πᵉₜ = πₜ₋₁ (or weighted average of past inflation)
mathematical_formulation.accelerationist_form: Δπ = -β(u - uⁿ) + ε when πᵉ = π₋₁
mathematical_formulation.long_run_condition: π = πᵉ → u = uⁿ (vertical long-run Phillips curve)
mathematical_formulation.sacrifice_ratio: SR = Σ(uₜ - uⁿ) / (π₀ - πᵀ) where T is end of disinflation
mathematical_formulation.new_keynesian_pc: πₜ = βE[πₜ₊₁] + κ(Yₜ - Y*) - forward-looking expectations

evolution_of_phillips_curve.original_phillips_1958: Purely empirical: wage inflation inversely related to unemployment - no theory of expectations
evolution_of_phillips_curve.samuelson_solow_1960: Interpreted as stable menu for policymakers - choose u/π combination
evolution_of_phillips_curve.friedman_phelps_1967_68: Added expectations - tradeoff only from surprise inflation. Natural rate hypothesis.
evolution_of_phillips_curve.lucas_1972: Rational expectations - even short-run tradeoff vanishes with credible policy announcements
evolution_of_phillips_curve.new_keynesian_1990s: Forward-looking expectations, micro-founded sticky prices: πₜ = βEπₜ₊₁ + κxₜ

policy_implications.no_long_run_tradeoff: Can't permanently reduce unemployment below natural rate by tolerating higher inflation
policy_implications.disinflation_costly: Reducing embedded inflation requires recession - sacrifice ratio 1.5-3.0
policy_implications.credibility_matters: If central bank credible, expectations adjust faster, disinflation less costly
policy_implications.nairu_uncertainty: Natural rate not directly observable, varies over time - policy must estimate it
policy_implications.supply_shocks_dilemma: Adverse supply shock (ε > 0) raises inflation AND unemployment - no good policy response

concepts: Regression analysis: Estimating Phillips curve parameters
Calculus: Acceleration and change in inflation
Central bank credibility: Political independence and inflation
Electoral cycles: Temptation to exploit short-run tradeoff before elections
Policy rules vs discretion: Time-inconsistency problem
Great Inflation 1970s: Breakdown of stable Phillips curve
Volcker disinflation: Costs of reducing inflation
1930s deflation: Extreme rightward movement on curve

provenance.verification_notes: Content verified against original Phillips (1958), Friedman (1968), and Phelps (1967) papers. Mathematical formulations confirmed in standard textbooks. Historical data verified with BLS and FRED. Sacrifice ratio estimates from Ball (1994).

verified_claims.claim: Expectations-augmented PC: π = πᵉ - β(u - uⁿ)
verified_claims.derivation: From labor market: W/W = f(u) + πᵉ. Markup pricing: P = (1+m)W. Taking growth rates: π = wage inflation = f(u) + πᵉ. With f(u) = -β(u - uⁿ): π = πᵉ - β(u - uⁿ) ✓

verified_claims.claim: Long-run Phillips curve is vertical at natural rate
verified_claims.derivation: In long run: πᵉ = π (expectations correct). Substituting: π = π - β(u - uⁿ), so 0 = -β(u - uⁿ), implying u = uⁿ for any π ✓

verified_claims.claim: Accelerationist hypothesis: Below NAIRU implies accelerating inflation
verified_claims.derivation: With adaptive expectations πᵉ = π₋₁: π = π₋₁ - β(u - uⁿ). If u < uⁿ: π > π₋₁, inflation rises. Each period: Δπ = -β(u - uⁿ) > 0. Inflation accelerates ✓
